title: 108_hr2682
content: The "Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2003" is cited as the short title. It includes a 20 percent reduction in estate tax rates according to an amendment in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2003 includes reduced tax rates based on specific income brackets, ranging from 14.4% to 19.2% for different income levels. The Estate Tax Reduction Act of 2003 introduces reduced tax rates based on income brackets, ranging from 14.4% to 19.2%. For incomes over $40,000 but not over $60,000, the tax is $10,400 plus 20.8% of the excess over $60,000. For incomes over $60,000 but not over $80,000, the tax is $14,560 plus 22.4% of the excess over $80,000. For higher incomes, the tax rates increase progressively. For incomes over $250,000 but not over $500,000, the tax is $56,640 plus 27.2% of the excess over $250,000. For incomes over $500,000 but not over $750,000, the tax is $124,640 plus 29.6% of the excess over $500,000. For incomes over $750,000 but not over $1,000,000, the tax is $198,640 plus 31.2% of the excess over $750,000. For incomes over $1,000,000 but not over $1,250,000. For incomes over $1,000,000 but not over $1,250,000, the tax is $276,640 plus 32.8% of the excess. For incomes over $1,250,000 but not over $1,500,000, the tax is $358,640 plus 34.4% of the excess. For incomes over $1,500,000 but not over $2,000,000, the tax is $444,640 plus 36% of the excess. For incomes over $2,000,000, the tax is $624,640 plus 39.2% of the excess. The amendment applies to estates and gifts over $2,000,000 for decedents dying after the enactment of the Act. Unified credit increased to $3,000,000 exclusion with inflation adjustment. Unified credit increased to $3,000,000 with inflation adjustment for decedents and gifts after 2003. The unified credit increased to $3,000,000 with inflation adjustment for decedents and gifts after 2003. Amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying and gifts made after the enactment of this Act.
